newsitem.title: JAPAN: JGB futures fall sharply on panicky selling.
newsitem.headline: JGB futures fall sharply on panicky selling.

text.p: Key June Japanese government bond (JGB) futures fell sharply in early Tokyo trade on Wednesday.
Aggressive selling was seen in the benchmark cash 182nd JGB and JGB futures after Tuesday's sharp fall, traders said.
The June contract was down 0.47 at 123.95 as of 9.40 a.m. (0040 GMT), after falling as low as 123.68.

"Panicky selling is continuing despite the weakness of Tokyo stocks this morning. People are choosing to sell benchmark cash and futures because of their high liquidity," said a trader at a trust bank's securities unit.
The yield of the 182nd JGB stood at 2.480 percent, after rising as high as 2.520 percent. It had ended at 2.420 percent on Tuesday.
JGBs fell sharply on Tuesday as the Nikkei 225 stock average surged.
The Nikkei's fall earlier on Wednesday morning, however, failed to improve sentiment in the bond market, traders said.
The key stock index was down 2.70 points at 20,178.22 as of 9.50 a.m. (0050 GMT) after falling to 20,074.31 earlier.
If the Nikkei rises into positive territory, that is likely to weigh on JGBs, traders said.
Traders see the key support point for June JGB futures as 123.60, which is this year's low set on January 6.
"If 123.60 does not hold, it would be difficult to predict the next support point," said a trader at another trust bank's securities unit.
Matsushita also said in a parliamentary committee meeting that monetary policy should not be relied on heavily to correct current account imbalances.
However the BOJ governor's comments did not have a lasting impact, traders said.
They said the direction of JGBs was likely to continue to depend on the Nikkei.
"If the Nikkei remains comfortably above 20,000, the market's perception of the economy could change. We might see more money flowing into stocks," said a trader at a trust bank's securities unit.
"Last year, money was flowing into bonds due to a lack of alternative investment vehicles. That situation may be changing," he added.
At midday, the yield of the benchmark 182nd JGB stood at 2.440 percent, after earlier rising as high as 2.520 percent. It closed at 2.420 percent on Tuesday.
